aws::graph::propositions: # Piper PA-28RT-201T Aircraft Ditching in Gulf of Mexico
Piper PA-28RT-201T with registration N2970G was substantially damaged following a ditching into the Gulf of Mexico on August 22, 2012, around 1140 eastern daylight time.
The private pilot was not injured in the accident.
Visual meteorological conditions prevailed during the flight.
No flight plan was filed for the personal flight.
The flight was conducted under the provisions of Title 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91.
The flight departed Knoxville Downtown Island Airport in Knoxville, Tennessee, around 0800.
The intended destination was St. Petersburg-Clearwater International Airport in St. Petersburg-Clearwater, Florida.
The pilot fueled the airplane prior to the accident flight.
While en route, the pilot maneuvered the airplane around several thunderstorms.
The engine began to run rough over the Gulf of Mexico.
The aircraft experienced a partial loss of engine power over the Gulf of Mexico.
The pilot declared an emergency after the engine problems began.
The pilot searched for a place to land and located a few islands nearby.
The pilot was unable to maintain altitude.
The pilot performed a gear-up landing in the water.
The airplane came to rest in approximately 3 to 4 feet of water.
The pilot egressed from the aircraft after ditching.
The U.S. Coast Guard rescued the pilot around 1215.
The pilot held a private pilot certificate with ratings for airplane single-engine land and instrument airplane.
The pilot's most recent Federal Aviation Administration third-class medical certificate was issued June 28, 2011.
The pilot reported 4,660 total hours of flight time.
The pilot reported 3,085 hours of flight time in the accident airplane make and model.
The Piper PA-28RT-201T was manufactured in 1979.
The Piper PA-28RT-201T was registered to the owner in 2006.
The aircraft was equipped with a Continental Motors TSIO-360-FB1B engine.
The Continental Motors TSIO-360-FB1B engine was rated at 200 horsepower.
The airplane's most recent annual inspection was completed on September 16, 2011.

text:
# Factual Information

## History of Flight

| | |
| --- | --- |
| Enroute-cruise | Loss of engine power (partial) (Defining event) |
| Emergency descent | Off-field or emergency landing |
| Emergency descent | Ditching |

On August 22, 2012, about 1140 eastern daylight time, a Piper PA-28RT-201T, N2970G, was substantially damaged following a ditching into the Gulf of Mexico, near Hernando Beach, Florida. The private pilot was not injured. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed, and no flight plan was filed for the personal flight, which was conducted under the provisions of Title 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91. The flight departed Knoxville Downtown Island Airport (DKX), Knoxville, Tennessee, about 0800 with the intended destination of St. Petersburg-Clearwater International Airport (PIE), St. Petersburg-Clearwater, Florida.

According to the pilot, he fueled the airplane prior to the accident flight. While en route, the pilot maneuvered the airplane around several thunderstorms before the engine began to run rough and experienced a partial loss of power over the Gulf of Mexico. The pilot declared an emergency, searched for a place to land, and located a few islands nearby. Unable to maintain altitude, the pilot performed a gear-up landing in the water, and the airplane came to rest in approximately 3 to 4 feet of water. The pilot egressed and was rescued by the U.S. Coast Guard around 1215.

The pilot held a private pilot certificate with ratings for airplane single-engine land and instrument airplane. His most recent Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) third-class medical certificate was issued June 28, 2011. He reported 4,660 total hours of flight time, of which 3,085 were in the accident airplane make and model.

According to FAA records, the airplane was manufactured in 1979 and registered to the owner in 2006. It was equipped with a Continental Motors TSIO-360-FB1B, 200-horsepower engine. The airplane's most recent annual inspection was completed on September 16, 2011.
